bestBHT.bht: James and John, two disciples of Jesus, sought places of honor in his kingdom. Jesus responded by explaining that such positions were not his to give, but were prepared by his Father for those he chose. Jesus also alluded to his own suffering and martyrdom, indicating that his disciples would share in this cup of suffering. James became the first martyr among the Twelve, while John endured a spiritual martyrdom throughout his life. This teaches us that following Jesus often involves enduring persecution and suffering for his name's sake.

Henry Alford: The one of these brethren was the first of the Apostles to drink the cup Of suffering, and be baptized with the baptism of blood.
The other had the longest experience among them of a life of trouble and persecution.
The last clause of the verse may be understood as in the text, ‘is not mine to give, but it shall be given to them for whom it is prepared of my Father.'
John Calvin: For though many believers die a natural death, and without violence or shedding of blood, yet it is common to all of them...to be conformed to the image of Christ."
During their whole life, they are sheep appointed to the slaughter."

We have now ascertained Christ’s meaning; for he does not here reason as to his power, but only desires us to consider for what purpose he was sent by the Father, and what corresponds to his calling...that we may not attempt to force our way into the hidden mysteries of God.
Philip Schaff: My cup indeed ye shall drink. James was the first martyr among the Twelve; John died a natural death at an advanced age, but in a spiritual sense his was the longest martyrdom.

Is not mine, etc. Either, it is not a boon to be gained by solicitation; or, it is not in my power, but it will be assigned to those for whom it has been prepared, according ‘to the eternal predestination of eternal positions in the kingdom of God.’ Yet these two might occupy the position.

Christ affirms that His will as Ruler in His kingdom accords with the eternal purpose of God; a purpose which forbade their ambitious solicitation, because its individual objects were as yet concealed.
Archibald T. Robertson: James was the first of the Twelve to meet the martyr's death.
John the last if reports are true about him.
John Gill: They should endure much persecution for his name's sake, as all that will live godly in Christ Jesus must expect in one shape or another.
James, being bathed in his own blood, when killed with the sword, and John being cast into a vessel of scalding oil, these are fitly expressed by a baptism.

Eternal life, or the heavenly glory, is a kingdom prepared by his Father, from the foundation of the world, and not for anybody, and every person, but for some only, according to his Father's sovereign will and pleasure.
John Wesley: Christ applies to the glories of heaven, what his disciples were so stupid as to understand of the glories of earth.
It is his to give in the strictest propriety, both as God, and as the Son of man.
He only asserts, that he gives it to none but those for whom it is originally prepared; namely, those who endure to the end in the faith that worketh by love.

bhtAttempts.bht: James and John, two of Jesus's disciples, were eager for places of honor and authority in his kingdom. Jesus responds by explaining that the position they sought was not his to give, but was prepared by his Father for those whom he had chosen. Jesus then refers to his own suffering and martyrdom, indicating that the cup of suffering and baptism of blood that he would experience would also be shared by his disciples. James, in fact, would be the first among the Twelve to drink from this cup, meeting a martyr's death. As for John, although he would not meet a similar fate, he would experience a lengthy spiritual martyrdom throughout his life. Jesus's words remind us that the path to glory in his kingdom often involves suffering and persecution, as all who desire to follow him can expect.

James and John desired positions of honor and authority in Jesus's kingdom, but he explained that such places were designated by his Father. Jesus then alluded to his own forthcoming suffering and martyrdom, indicating that his disciples would also experience this cup of suffering. James would be the first to drink from it, meeting a martyr's death, while John would endure a spiritual martyrdom throughout his life. This reminds us that following Jesus often means enduring suffering and persecution, as those who desire to follow him can expect.
